field_reports.description:
On September 25, the Department of Hydrology and Metrology (DHM, GoN) issued a weather advisory for a new spell of monsoon, influenced by the moisture-laden winds from the Bay of Bengal and the local weather system, to remain active between 26 and 29 September with the potential to cause heavy rainfall in most of the provinces, triggering flash floods, landslides and overflow of rivers. This forecast turns into reality with heavy rainfall noticed in Bagmati and Gandaki provinces and moderately heavy rain in other provinces. In the last 24 hours, the rainfall has been stopped in all the provinces. However, the water level in Bagmati and Koshi rivers are still above danger level, gradually falling down.

Reports of major and minor highways being washed away or severely eroded due to landslides and river erosion have emerged. The main highway – Kathmandu to Naryangadh – connecting Kathmandu to the rest of Nepal is currently inaccessible, with frequent mudslides at several locations, rendering it impassable for traffic and pedestrians. Similarly, massive blockages have been reported on other highways across the western and eastern Terai and in hilly areas. Buses were buried and many lives were lost in the Prithiv highway. Still security forces are conducting rescue in the buried vehicles. According to media report, 35 dead bodies were taken out from the debris. 

The entire Kathmandu valley was inundated on 27 and 28 September which has submerged many houses in the valley. Since the rainfall was stopped from 28 September, the water level has returned to its normal range in all rivers in Kathmandu valley. The water has resided from inundated areas. There was no significant damage in the houses wheras household items are affected due to inundation. People have started cleaning their houses. 

Till date, 104 people lost their lives, 73 injured and 64 are still missing according to Nepal Police.

field_reports.description:
On September 25, the Department of Hydrology and Metrology (DHM, GoN) issued a weather advisory for a new spell of monsoon, influenced by the moisture-laden winds from the Bay of Bengal and the local weather system, to remain active between 26 and 29 September with the potential to cause heavy rainfall in most of the provinces, triggering flash floods, landslides and overflow of rivers. This forecast turns into reality with heavy rainfall noticed in Bagmati and Gandaki provinces and moderately heavy rain in other provinces. In the last 24 hours, seven locations in Koshi province received above 120 to 140 mm rainfall, above 30 locations in Bagmati received above 140mm rainfall, and around 6 locations in Gandaki province received high to very high rainfall, while the rainfall in other provinces remains between moderate and high with minimal impact on lives and properties.

 The impact of this short but intensified rainfall across the country is evident from the real-time data: Over 101 of 272 real-time metrological stations observed the river crossing the danger level in the last 24 hours. The rainfall is expected to dissipate in the coming hours, with the possibility of scattered light to heavy rainfall throughout the country.

 In the early morning of 28 Sep. 24, multiple sources reported that nearly all streams and rivers in the Kathmandu Valley had overflowed, surpassing the danger levels and flooding nearby settlements along the riverbanks. Although there is no confirmed data on the extent of the damage yet, initial estimates suggest that over ten thousand people may be seeking refuge in open areas. It is expected that the floodwaters will take several hours to decrease.

 Reports of major and minor highways being washed away or severely eroded due to landslides and river erosion have emerged. The main highway – Kathmandu to Naryangadh – connecting Kathmandu to the rest of Nepal is currently inaccessible, with frequent mudslides at several locations, rendering it impassable for traffic and pedestrians. Similarly, massive blockages have been reported on other highways across the western and eastern Terai and in hilly areas. Kalikandaki corridor, a lifeline for at least three Syangja, Banglung and Parbat districts, is reportedly blocked due to several small to large landslides. Similarly, the Araniko highway is currently not passable due to numerous landslides along the road and a bridge collapse, a critical logistical corridor for Nepal to get supplies from China. 

 The water levels in the tributaries of the Koshi basin have increased, and the water level has reached both warning and danger levels. The flow of the Saptakoshi River was measured at 449,680 cusecs at 9 AM on Saturday. This is above the danger level. All 56 gates have been opened. We are actively trying to gather more information from the field. So far, DHM has already sent out 2 SMS alerts in the area since yesterday evening. Fortunately, the water has not yet entered the settlement areas (UN Situation Report, dated 28 Sept).

 The situation is expected to continue for several days, disrupting the supply of goods across the country as the festive season begins. This is likely to hike the price for essential commodities and may cause the stock to be out of stock if the roads remain impassable for several days. Debris cleaning remains challenging owing to the increasing number of sites requiring immediate attention and the severe lack of heavy equipment. 

 For the second time after 25 years, both gates of Kulekhani Dam were opened as the water level reached a hazardous level due to continuous rainfall in the catchment area. This caused havoc in low-lying areas of Makawanpur, Kathmandu, Sarlahi, and Mahottari. Extensive details of the damages to lives and properties are out of reach at this stage.

So far, there have been reports of around 22 districts affected by floods and landslides.

results.name: Nepal: Floods EAP, 2024
results.summary:
Flood is the most severe of the hazards observed in Nepal in terms of physical and socioeconomic losses and destruction. Koshi, Karnali, and Narayani are the major river systems in Nepal, and floods from these large perennial river systems generally impact several districts in the Southern Terai plains. Moreover, rivers such as West Rapti, and Babai Rivers, which originate in the Mahabharat range, do more damage in the Terai floodplains because they frequently generate flash floods during the monsoon. Moreover, the Terai's vulnerable topography, combined with its dependency on agriculture, exacerbates the severity of flood hazards compared to other regions.
 
In 2017, the prolonged rainfall across Nepal from 11-14 August 2017 brought flooding across 31 districts of Nepal. The southern Terai region was particularly affected with an estimated 450,000 people affected by flooding, 43 people were killed. According to the Government of Nepal, National Planning Commission Post Disaster Need Assessment Report (PDNA) 2017, it has been estimated that 41,626 houses were destroyed, and 150,510 houses were damaged by the flooding. Over 126,282 ha of paddy were damaged during the flooding, with higher-value crops such as vegetables and aquaculture also suffering significantly. Moreover, the flooding affected over 812,000 poultry, 9,400 cattle, and 74,000 sheds.
 
The targeted flood-prone areas are the Terai districts along the flood plains of Karnali, Babai and West Rapti rivers, namely Banke, Bardiya and Kailali. frequently affected due to flooding in the monsoon period. People living along these rivers especially low-lying areas, informal settlements, fragile houses, and those who have lowincome status and a number of dependent family members to care for, are highly vulnerable to flooding. 
 
NRCS has undertaken extensive household data collection along the flood plains of Karnali, Babai & West Rapti River basins 2021-2022. The analysis shows that 33,794 families are living in Tikapur Municipality, Janaki Rural Municipality, Geruwa Rural Municipality, Rajapur Municipality and Madhuwan Municipality along the Karnali river. Likewise, 25,247 families are living in Barbardiya Municipality, Thakurbaba Municipality, Madhuwan Municipality and Gulariya Municipality along the Babai River. And 21032 families are living in Rapti Sonari Rural Municipality, Duduwa Rural municipality, and Narinapur Rural Municipality along the West Rapti.

field_reports.description:
The preliminary reports came from the filed revels that the fire incidences were occured initially in forest was spred to the communities which has caught in public houses and cattle sheds. Accordingto the sources, in Arghakhnachi District, Four municipalities/rural municipalities have been affected namely Shitganga Municipality (ward no.-6,7,10 and 11), Panini rural municipality (ward no.-3 and 8), Bhumikasthan Municipality (Ward no.-3,4,5, and 9) and Chhtradev Rural municipality (ward no. 4). In Arghakhanchi district a total of 59 houses and 37 cattle sheds were caught by the fire. The details of the affected families and losses have yet to come from the affected areas.

Likewise, in Gulmi district, Isma rural muncipality (ward no-2)was affected by the fire which was initially begun in nearby forest. The preliminary report came from the district have showed that there were atotal of 38 houses including cattle sheds were caught by the fire. Due to the fire 2 people were injured who were taken to nearby hospital for treatment. The fire has resulted kill a total of 40 buffaloes and goats.

In both the districts security foreces, local people and forest division staff have been involved to take control of the fire.

field_reports.description: The preliminary information received from Kapilvastu Dsitrict Chapter reveals that today there was a fire incidence in about four municipalities. It has come to know that around 50 houses have caught under the fire. In Yashodhara Rural Municipality about 45 houses have been caught by the fire in eard no. 1 and 6. It was also reported that some tracktors have also been burnt due to the fire. In Sudhodhan Rural Municipality about 6 houses were caught under fire and Wheat crops have also been burnt in the field. Till now, it was revealed that the property of around 7.5 million rupees is damaged due to the fire. However the number of houses and property loss/damage may be increased as the time passes on. The government security personnel and Red Cross Volunteers are still in the field to help the people affected by the fire although it is night time

field_reports.description:
According to National online news report Onlinekhar.com and further contact with Nepal Red Cross Society, Morang, Bhojpur and Terhathum District Chapters have revealed that there have been different incidences of fire in the above mentioned districts. 

In Morang District,  there were incidence of fire at Santhar, Satar and Mushhar communities of Rangeli Municipality-3.  The incidence has completely burned 20 houses directly affecting 23 families. Accroding to Ranjan Dahal, Deputy Superintendent of Police, District Police, Morang the fire incidence was started at 2 PM on 16 March which was taken full control at 4:00 AM of the following day only. A total of 7 fire brigades were mobilized to take control of the fire. The affected families are taking shelter in bearby place under the tarpaulin. The local government has made annoucement that the affected families will be provided with NPR. 50,000.00 support to recostruct the damaged houses.

Accroding to President of Nepal Red Red Cross Society, Morang District Chapter has mobilized its human resources to support the affected families with Non-food releif item. An assessment conudcted by the NRCS showed that a total of 28 houses were fully brunt affecting 28 families comprising 64 male and 59 famale. All the families are displaced and taking shelter nearby safe place.

In Bhojpur District, a fire incidence has caused death of 3 children in Hatuwagadi Rual Municipality-7. The fire which was initially ignited in a cowshed spread over and that caught the children who were playing nearby. The local police has mobilized a team to inquire about the incidence. Similary, there was an another fire incidence at Malbase in Taksar of Bhojpur Municipality-12.  The fire inidence was occured due to entring the forest fire into the neary community resulting damang of 6 houses. The local Police and nepal Army were moilized to take control of the fire.

Accroding to President of Nepal Red Red Cross Society, Bhojpur District Chapter has mobilized its human resources to support the affected families with Non-food releif item.

field_reports.description:
A magnitude of 6.4 earthquake hit western part of Nepal on 3 November 2023 at mid night 11:47 pm in Karnali Province of Nepal. The epicenter of the earthquake was at Lamidanda, Jajarkot. Several aftershocks are being experienced till date. According to the Nepal Government, there is a death of 157 people and 205 injured in Jajarkot and Rukum West districts. Atleast 14,000 houses are affected in those areas. Due to the remoteness of affected areas, communication inturruption and road blockage, it is being difficult to get the actual updates and transport relief materials. Continuous aftershocks have forced people to leave houses and stay in open spaces. However, Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS) EOC team is regularly coordinating the district chapters' focal persons to get the updated information. NRCS Sectoral focal persons are also actively engaged in the earthquake response activities.

NRCS volunteers and staff are actively engaged in search and rescue from day one. The injured people are being referred to district hospitals and hub hospital Surkhet and Nepalgunj. Now, NRCS district chapter is conducting Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA). Nepal Government (NEOC) has also provided sole responsibility to NRCS for assessment process. For technical support, NRCS EOC has deployed three ERT (Emergency Response Team) members in each of the districts.  Two Psychosocial Support (PSS) volunteers are also mobilized in the affected districts. They have already reached to affected districts and they have been continuously supporting the affected people and colleting data and sending to EOC. Similarly, EOC meeting on 4 November at 8 am decided to dispatch relief items: blanket (1200 pcs), tarpaulin (1200 pcs), mattress (1200 pcs), plastic rope (800 pcs) and plastic bucket (200 pcs) in two affected districts. 250 dead body bags were also sent in the affected districts. In addition, 200 pcs of mattressess will be promptly handed over to two district hospitals.

A magnitude of 6.4 earthquake hit western part of Nepal on 3 November 2023 at mid night 11:47 pm in Karnali Province of Nepal. The epicenter of the earthquake was at Lamidanda, Jajarkot. Several aftershocks are being experienced till date. According to the Nepal Government, there is a death of 133 people and 140 injured in Jajarkot and Rukum West districts. More than 4,000 houses are affected in those areas. Due to the remoteness of affected areas, communication inturruption and road blockage, it is being difficult to get the actual updates and transport relief materials. Continuous aftershocks have forced people to leave houses and stay in open spaces. However, Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS) EOC team is regularly coordinating the district chapters' focal persons to get the updated information. NRCS Sectoral focal persons are also actively engaged in the earthquake response activities.

NRCS volunteers and staff are actively engaged in search and rescue from the mid-night. The injured people are being referred to district hospitals and hub hospital Surkhet and Nepalgunj. Now, NRCS district chapter is conducting Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA). Nepal Government (NEOC) has also provided sole responsibility to NRCS for assessment process. For technical support, NRCS EOC has deployed three ERT (Emergency Response Team) members in each of the districts.  Two Psychosocial Support (PSS) volunteers are also mobilized in the affected districts. They are on their way to affected districts. Similarly, EOC meeting on 4 November at 8 am decided to dispatch relief items: blanket (1200 pcs), tarpaulin (1200 pcs), mattress (1200 pcs), plastic rope (800 pcs) and plastic bucket (200 pcs) in two affected districts. 250 dead body bags were also sent in the affected districts. In addition, 200 pcs of mattressess will be promptly handed over to two district hospitals.

An earthquake of 6.4 Richter scale with the epicenter at Lamidanda, Jajarkot hit at mid night 11:47 PM in Karnali Province of Nepal. The tremor of the earthquke was also felt in adjoining districts including Kathmandu. The initial report published in ekantpur news states that according to District Suprendent of Police (DSP) of Rukum and District Administration Office (CDO) of Jajarkot there is a death of 12 and 8 people respectively in the districts. There might be even more causalitities in the districts since the incidence was occured at mid night the information is yet to come. Based on initial report published in the the newpaper, 3 houses and 7 houses are collapse in Aathbiskot Municipality and Triveni Rural Municipality of Rukum West district. 1 house dmanged in Subhakali Rural Municipality of Kalikot district. In Jajarkot district Bheri Municipality, Nalgadh Municipality, Barekoot Rural Municipality and Kushe Municipality have been affected severely. More than 100 people have been reached in local hospital for treatment in Jajarkot. It is assumed that around 40% of houses are damaged by the earthquake in Jajarkot. The district police has requested to general public for involving in Search and Rescue Operation to find out the possibly affected people. There is a high possibility of after shockes in these area. The CDO and Police has requested general public to inform if they need immediate rescue in the affected area.

field_reports.description: According to National Earthquakr Monitoring and Research Center, Department of Mines and Geology, Nepal there was an earthquake of 6.1 ML (Richter scale) with the epicenter in nearby Khari, Dhading district at 7:39 local time (UTC 1:54). Since the first tremor there were another 3 aftershocks felt with the magnitude of 4.2ML, 4.3ML and 4.1ML at 8.08, 8.28 and 8.59 local time respectively with epicenter at Dhaing itself. The tremors of the earthquake were also felt in Kathmandu, Gorkha, Nuwakot, Makwanpur, and Chitwan. Immediately after the first tremor NRCS, EOC has contacted Dhading and Chitwan District Chapters and inquire about the possible impact of the tremor. According to respective President of the chatpters, there were no infromation about the any type of causalities reported yet in both the districts. However, EOC is in continuous in-touch with other adjoing districts also to get reports of any possible impacts of the earthquake.

field_reports.description:
A magnitude of 5.3 earthquake hit western Nepal on Monday, 3 October 2022, at 14.40 PM local time. Strong aftershock with 6.3 Richter scale occurred immediately after main shock at 15:06 PM and second after shock of 5.1 Richter scale recorded. The epicenter of the quake was located in Bajhang district. Tremors were felt in neighboring districts (Doti, Achham, Bajura, Dadeldhura, Baitadi and Darchula) as well as Kathmandu, Nepal and also in New Delhi, India.  Initially, it was reported that earthquake has impacted houses, schools and public building. In the earthquake affected districts people are staying in open spaces, neighbor houses and the nearest schools that are located in the safe place.

According to situation report published by Provincial Emergency Operation Centre (PEOC) of Sudur-Paschim Province, moderate impact has been reported in seven districts. Data received from districts are as follows:

Doti district: The impact of earthquake is nominal in the district. As per the PEOC situation report, there is no any human casualty however, 1 house is partially damaged and 8 school buildings are damaged.

Achham district: The earthquake has damaged 12 house fully, 2 houses are partially, 15 people are displaced and 5 people are injured.

Bajura district: As per the IRA report received from district, 199 houses are fully damaged, 548 houses are partially damaged and 2 people are injured in this district.

Bajhang district: As per the IRA report received from district, 91 houses are fully damaged, 318 houses are partially damaged, 20 people are injured and 1 woman is missing due to landslide triggered by the earthquake. One section of main highway (Jaya Prithvi highway) is blocked due to landslide the district is isolated from road transportation service.

Dadeldhura district: 4 houses are partially damaged and there is no any further impact so far.

Baitadi district: 2 houses are fully damaged, 3 houses are partially damaged and 2 people are injured in this district.

Darchula district: 1 house is partially damaged and the impact of earthquake is comparatively less in this district.

Nepal Red Cross Society is working in the affected districts to distribute the tarpaulins, collecting detail information. Further details about the activities are described below:

One section of main highway (Jaya Prithvi highway) is blocked due to landslide the district is isolated from road transportation service.

Dadeldhura district: 4 houses are partially damaged and there is no any further impact so far.

Baitadi district: 2 houses are fully damaged, 3 houses are partially damaged and 2 people are injured in this district.

Darchula district: 1 house is partially damaged and the impact of earthquake is comparatively less in this district.

Nepal Red Cross Society is working in the affected districts to distribute the tarpaulins, collecting detail information. Further details about the activities are described below.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: As of 3 August,2023 a total of 7,253 dengue cases have been identified from 71 districts, with Koshi province reporting highest number (5101), followed by Bagmati province (1171), Gandaki Province (389) and Sudurpaschim Province (342). The top 10 districts account for 88 % of all reported cases (6,398 cases), while the cases are sporadic in other districts. These top 10 districts include Sunsari (4,679), Dhading (829), Kaski (214) Darchula (191), Kathamandu (119), Jhapa (81) Sankhuwasabha (75), Dhankuta (74) Morang (72) and Kanchanpur (64). The mortality of seven dengue cases has been verified, with one case associated with severe dengue shock syndrome, and the remaining six cases resulting from dengue along with other comorbidities. The situation is expected to further deteriorate in coming months due to the monsoon rain and humid climate which is most fertile environment for mosquito breeding. Since monsoon is continued, and continuous rainfall accumulated stagnant water in all affected districts and communities. So there is a high possibilities of Dengue transmission in coming months.
field_reports.description:
In Nepal, dengue is a rapidly emerging disease. Endemic across most provinces, dengue incidence has increased in recent years largely due to expansion of the vector Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, as well as the movement of people and the introduction of imported cases. All 4 dengue serotypes exist in Nepal, with DENV-1 and 2 historically contributing the highest burden (EDCD, 2019). The first case of dengue in Nepal was reported in 2004. Since then, dengue cases have been gradually reported in Nepal, with an outbreak in the year 2019 (n=17,992) reported from 68 districts and in 2022 (n=54,784) from all 77 districts. According to EDCD of MoHP, among the total of 54,000 cases, majority of dengue cases (n=28109) including 38 deaths happened between January to September 2022 coinciding with the peak rainy season in the country. This is indicative of exponential surge in dengue cases during July/ September considering the overall weather conditions and monsoon season which provides hibernating infected mosquitoes with an optimal environment for breeding. Until epidemiological week 29 (first week of August 2023, EWARS report, EDCD), 7,253 dengue cases has already been diagnosed which is highly alarming as this is the very first time that dengue has occurred in the consecutive year in contrary to the usual cyclical pattern of dengue incidence in Nepal. In addition, dengue incidence started even during winter season and is in increasing trend. According to a mathematical modelling projection conducted by WHO (2022), the projection shows that cases have already exceeded the alert threshold since beginning of 2023 when compared to the reported dengue cases in EWARS, indicating Dengue outbreak in Nepal. Since dengue is relatively new for Nepal, there is low level of knowledge and awareness among people. Even the priority for dengue prevention was less priority in the country until last year, Nepal government has been sincerely trying to address the emerging trend of dengue through joint planning and implementation from this year. Therefore, Nepal government, municipal authority to the national level, have requested NRCS for better coordination and collaboration in dengue prevention and response to the current outbreak. 
Furthermore, Dengue has disparate effect on different population strata. While pregnant and lactating women, children and elderly population are vulnerable to dengue, young adult population working outside (with low socio-economic status) have higher exposure risk to dengue infected vectors. The number of hospitalized cases has increased exponentially overwhelming the health facilities in Sunsari district. The current daily average cases shows that similar situation might be experienced in the affected districts in coming weeks or months. 
Likewise, the supply of blood (Platelets-rich Plasma-PRPs) will be the challenge to meet the demand. Because of all these factors the severity and mortality cases will be increased in the country. In addition, the urban design of major cities in Nepal lacks in infrastructural public health aspects along with challenging waste management system and poor sanitation facilities which provides vectors with optimal environment for breeding. People residing in slums, densely populated urban cities with poor sanitation facilities are at greater risk of being affected.

field_reports.description:
In Nepal, dengue is a rapidly emerging disease. Endemic across most provinces, dengue incidence has increased in recent years largely due to expansion of the vector Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, as well as the movement of people and the introduction of imported cases. All 4 dengue serotypes exist in Nepal, with DENV-1 and 2 historically contributing the highest burden (EDCD, 2019). The first case of dengue in Nepal was reported in 2004. Since then, dengue cases have been gradually reported in Nepal, with an outbreak in the year 2019 (n=17,992) reported from 68 districts and in 2022 (n=54,784) from all 77 districts.  According to EDCD of MoHP, among the total of 54,000 cases, majority of dengue cases (n=28109) including 38 deaths happened between January to September 2022 coinciding with the peak rainy season in the country. This is indicative of exponential surge in dengue cases during July/ September considering the overall weather conditions and monsoon season which provides hibernating infected mosquitoes with an optimal environment for breeding. Until epidemiological week 17 (end of April 2023, EWARS report, EDCD), 600 dengue cases has already been diagnosed which is highly alarming as this is the very first time that dengue has occurred in the consecutive year in contrary to the usual cyclical pattern of dengue incidence in Nepal.
In addition, dengue incidence started even during winter season and is steadily rising over the weeks. According to a mathematical modelling projection conducted by WHO (2022), the projection shows that cases are already exceeded the alert threshold since beginning of 2023 when compared to the reported dengue cases in EWARS, indicating early signs on outbreak in Nepal. On average, 20-30 cases of dengue have been found each week in different regions of Nepal. 
Since dengue is relatively new for Nepal, there is low level of knowledge and awareness among people. Even the priority for dengue prevention was less priority in the country until last year, Nepal government has been sincerely trying to address the emerging trend of dengue through joint planning and implementation from this year. Therefore, Nepal government, municipal authority to the national level, have requested NRCS for better coordination and collaboration in dengue prevention initiatives. 
Ongoing reported cases of COVID-19 and dengue infection has overarching effects on country’s health system with challenges to properly manage the cases. Furthermore, Dengue has disparate effect on different population strata. While pregnant and lactating women, children and elderly population are vulnerable to dengue, young adult population working outside (with low socio-economic status) have higher exposure risk to dengue infected vectors. Hence, the number of hospitalized cases will be increased in coming 3-4 months and hospital facilities will be overwhelmed. Likewise, the supply of blood (Platelets-rich Plasma-PRPs) will be the challenge to meet the demand. Because of all these factors the severity and mortality cases will be increased in the country. 
In addition, the urban design of major cities in Nepal lacks in infrastructural public health aspects along with challenging waste management system and poor sanitation facilities which provides vectors with optimal environment for breeding. People residing in slums, densely populated urban cities with poor sanitation facilities are at greater risk of being affected. Hence, exponential rise in dengue cases can not only overwhelm health systems but also affect the most vulnerable population with low socio-economic conditions.

field_reports.description:
According to Hot Day and Heat wave Bulletin 4 published by Department of Hydrology and Meteorology, the temperature of most of the part of Nepal is increasing and the Terai districts of Far-Western and Lumbini Provinces are facing extreme heat i.e. more than 40 degree Celsius. There is probability of hot wind and head wave; therefore, awareness raising campaigns are being launched in those areas. Radios and Televisions are announcing the precautions to save from heat and Red Cross volunteers are orienting and distributing IEC materials in those target areas. Due to high population density with concrete built-up areas in the urban areas, the daily wages workers, women, children, elderly people and chronic illness people are most vulnerable and need special attention as well. Heatwaves is not only affecting the health of people but also their livelihoods.

NDRRMA (National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority) under Ministry of Home Affairs have developed and disseminated Heat wave preparedness and response plan 2024. Local Governments of affected and to be affected areas are also coordinating with Red Cross and other relevant stakeholders for saving the lives of people from hot wind and heat wave.

If temperature in these areas keep increasing over coming 3-4 days, the health condition of people will be deteriorated in the districts situated in southern belt of Nepal. Heatwave aggravated by forest fire, air pollutions and emergence of different infectious diseases can have disproportionate effects. 


In terms of heatwave, the most commonly children, elderly population, pregnant and lactating mothers, people with disability and daily wage labors/ people with low-income will have direct impact on their health, nutrition and living conditions. The extreme hot weather may have direct affect on health due to high incidence of dengue in approaching monsoon with overarching effects on overall health system. As a result cardiovascular effects to elderly population due to prolonged heatwaves including aggravated effects due to underlying health conditions may occur in these areas. Furthermore, extreme heat can increase the risk for preterm birth, low birth weight, fetal death, and infant mortality alongwith heat related injuries and illness among daily-wage workers due to exposure to prolonged heat.

field_reports.description:
According to National Earthquake Monitoring and R esearch Center of Nepal,  earthquake with 5.3 Richter scale occurred in Bajhang District in Sudur Paschim Province of Nepal at 14:40 on 03 October 2023. Strong aftershock with 6.3 Richter scale occurred immediately after main shock at 15:06 and second after shock of 5.1 Richter scale at 15:13 and after shock 4.1 at 15:45recorded. The epicenter of the quake was located in Bajhang district. Tremor was felt in surrounding districts (Bajura, Bajhang, Achham, Bajura, Dadeldhura, Baitadi, Darchula) as well as Kathmandu and also in Delhi, India.

 

 

The Emergency Operation (EOC) Team from NHQs has been continuously communicating with these district chapters and collected information about impact of the earthquake. Based on the telephonic communication in NRCS district chapters in these districts, they have immediately mobilized their volunteers to collect information about impact of the earthquake and also to conduct Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA).

Preliminary report received from NRCS district shows that there is not any human casualties so far. According to NRCS Doti chapter there is no any significant damages are reported so far however NRCS volunteers are still trying to reach in remote villages to collect more information. According to NRCS Bajhang chapter there is no any human casualty reported so far however 1 person is still missing. I nBajhang 13 palikas are affected due to the earthquake. Based n IRA reports 64 houses are fully destroyed and 274 houses are partially damaged. In Achham district 62  houses are fully destroyed and 590 houses are partially damaged. Whereas, 1 student was injured during the time of earthquake due to jumping from school building while tremor was active. 3 palikas are affected due to earthquke in Achham. Based on IRA report from NRCS Bajura district chapter 1441 houses are fully destroyed and 4737 houses are partially damanged. Altogether 7 Rural Municipality/municipalties are affected due to the earthquake.In Doti district 9 houses are partilaly affected. Similalry, in Baitadi district 10 houses are fully destroyed and 4 houses are partially damaged. Likewise, 3 houses are partially demaged in Darchula district. Furthermore, 4 houses are partially damaged in Dadeldhura district

NRCS NHQs is collecting additional reports from all these districts and data verification is stil going to find out the exact number of houses damaged and people affected dur to the earthquake.

field_reports.description:
According to national Earthquake Montiorign and research Center of Nepal,  earthquake with 5.3 Richter scale occurred in Bajhang District in Sudur Paschim Province of Nepal at 14:40 on 03 October 2023. Strong aftershock with 6.3 Richter scale occurred immediately after main shock at 15:06 and second after shock of 5.1 Richter scale at 15:13 and after shock 4.1 at 15:45recorded. The epicenter of the quake was located in Bajhang district. Tremor was felt in surrounding districts (Bajura, Bajhang, Achham, Bajura, Dadeldhura, Baitadi, Darchula) as well as Kathmandu and also in Delhi, India.

The Emergency Operation (EOC) Team from NHQs has been communicating with these district chapters and trying to collect information about impact of the earthquake. Based on the telephonic communication with NRCS district chapters in these districts, they have been mobilizing their volunteers to collect information about impact of the earthquake and also to conduct Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA).

Preliminary report received from NRCS district shows that there is not any human casualties so far According to NRCS Doti chapter there is no any significant damages are reported so far however NRCS volunteers are still trying to reach in remote villages to collect more information. According to NRCS Bajhang chapter there is no any human casualty reported so far however chapter team have received telephone call from various places and reported that more than 200 houses are damaged but the exact numbers yet to be confirmed. One school building (Two-room building) is collapsed in Achham district, and one student injured. The impact on houses and other infrastructure is not reported yet however volunteers are collecting more information in the district as well. As per preliminary information received from NRCS Bajura district chapter (telephonic information), around 500 houses are affected in Khaptad Chhededaha Rural Municipality which are not safe to live in. Similarly, more than 5 houses are affected in Budhi Ganga Municipality. However, district chapter volunteer are conducting IRA in this municipality as well as in other parts of the district. NRCS NHQs is collecting additional reports from all these districts and updated information will be shared immediately if any additional report about damages is collected.

field_reports.description:
At 2.43 PM on 24 January 2023, a 5.9 magnitude earthquake with an epicenter occurred in the Himali Rural Municipality of Bajura district from Sudurpaschim province according to National Earthquake Monitoring and Research Centre. According to Nepal Government authorities, one person was reported dead, three others injured and up to 42 households were damaged after an earthquake struck, with authorities still searching for damage. In addition, the shock of the earthquake was felt more in the hilly districts of the region and damaged 11 households in the adjoining Bhajhang district. People have come out of their houses after the earthquake and are taking temporary shelters with their relatives.

 

Likewise, District Disaster Management Committee (DDMC) had a quick meeting and requested 200 tarpaulins, 300 blankets, and mattresses with the NRCS Bajura district chapter to provide immediate relief support to the affected families.

field_reports.description:
At 2:12 AM on 9 November 2022, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurred with an epicenter located in Dipayal Municipality, Doti District of Sudur Paschim Province, within the sparsely populated area around Khaptad National Park. According to the National Seismological Center, there were many aftershocks till Saturday 12 November 2022. Nepal Government authorities have reported six people dead and seven injured in Purbichauki Rural Municipality, Doti District.

As per the initial data received by Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS) from the affected districts, a total of 30,625 people/6,125 households were affected (fully or partially) by the earthquake incident in Doti, Achham, Bajura, and Bajhang districts. As of 12 November 2022, 20 temporary shelters has been built by NRCS in Purbichauki Rural municipality (one of the worst affected Municipality by an earthquake) of Doti district, while families and individuals of other affected districts are taking temporary shelters with their relatives. NRCS Doti district chapter immediately deployed the search and rescue team including one emergency response team member in coordination with local authorities in the affected area. The volunteers and staff are assessing damages, providing first aid and cooking meals at affected areas.

A coordination meeting was organized by NRCS on 12 November 2022 with the participation from the IFRC and in country partner national societies, based upon the available data and needs; a DREF will be activated soon to provide immediate relief support to the affected population.

A magnitude 6.6 earthquake hit western Nepal on Wednesday 9 November 2022 early morning at 2:12 AM. The epicenter of the quake was located in Dipayal Municipality, Doti District of Sudur Paschim Province, within the sparsely populated area around Khaptad National Park. The tremor was felt in neighboring districts (Bajhang, Kailali, Kanchanpur, Banke, Rukum west) as well as in the bordering area of India.

 

Nepal Government authorities have reported six casualties and seven injured in Prubichauki Rural Municipality, Doti District. An initial rapid assessment shows that a total of 225 households were affected by the earthquake, where 30 were fully damaged. In addition, estimated 15 houses are reported to be affected by a landslide triggered by the earthquake in Bajhang District. Now, affected families are taking temporary shelters with their relatives. The most pressing problem facing the humanitarian effort is access to the affected populations and areas, with roads, communication, and electricity currently reported to be disrupted.

 

Currently, the urgent efforts to address immediate emerging humanitarian needs to provide dignity kit for vulnerable women (who are pregnant and lactating mothers) and further support for elderly people, and people with disabilities.

 

NRCS Doti district chapter immediately deployed the search and rescue team including one emergency response team member in coordination with local authorities in the affected area. The district chapter and subchapter provided 20 NFRI promptly after the earthquake. NRCS headquarter is closely monitoring the situation and communicating regularly with the district chapter and field staff for further assistance.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Sporadic cases of cholera and diarrhea were reported in the Kathmandu valley and many other districts of Nepal. As of 28 June 2022, 14 cases are under treatment in Kathmandu Valley and no death reported to date. While this is initial spread only, these cases are happening in high-density settlements with below-standard hygiene situations.
field_reports.description:
Overall situation: Diarrhea and cholera cases have been detected in Nepal Since 16 June 2022. As of 29 June 2022, no fatalities were yet reported. Monsoon seasons exacerbate the risk of an outbreak. Nepal Red Cross Society has requested DREF support. The Government of Nepal has continued the active surveillance in the affected places. Few areas are under particular surveillance by authorities. 
NRCS Actions: Nepal Red Cross Society was requested to scale up community engagement and risk awareness measures. NRCS is closely coordinating with the WAS cluster. In 29 June, NRCS shared an initial plan for response with IFRC and partners and an initial coordinating meeting was held on 30 June 2022. The second coordination meeting was held on 1 July 2022 and NRCS requested the IFRC for DREF Support. The proposed integrated plan combines community health, WASH and RC-CEA interventions and is planned for the duration of the monsoon season which is increasing the risk of the outbreak particularly as the monsoon is predicted higher than average this year.

Due to unseasonal rainfall since Sunday, 17 October 2021 in different parts of the country, floods, and landslides have struck again in Nepal, where Baitadi, Kalikot, Doti, Dadeldhura, Darchula, Bajhang, Kailali, Sindhuli, Udayapur, Bhojpur, Illam Dhunkuta, Panchthar, Humla, Sunsari, Jhapa, and Kanchanpur districts reported 77 fatalities, 26 missing and 31 injured in the last two days. Water levels in the Mahakali, Bheri, Karnali, Koshi, Gandaki, West-Rapti and other rivers are likely to rise further this week because of heavy rains. Meanwhile, rainfall has caused damages at different road sections and bridges along the main highways at various locations, affecting the relief responses. Also, electricity, telephones, and the internet are interrupted in different districts. 

Data of last two days shows that a total of 5,415 families are affected, 3385 families have been displaced and 2,022 households (fully 576 and partially 1446) have been damaged across 17 districts (Baitadi, Kalikot, Doti, Dadeldhura, Darchula, Bajhang, Kailali, Sindhuli, Udayapur, Bhojpur, Illam Dhunkuta, Panchthar, Humla, Sunsari, Jhapa, and Kanchanpur districts). The displaced families are residing in public buildings, schools, and neighborhoods. Displaced families have lost access to water points and sanitation facilities, increasing the risk of health problems, water-borne diseases, and the spread of COVID-19 infection in the community. Rescue, evacuation, and assessment are still ongoing in affected districts. (The number of people affected and displaced might change). Moreover, according to different local governments, there is rising in the number of people and households affected by the calamity. The flood and landslide have caused damage to crops and livestock in the affected districts. This month (October-November) was the peak hour to harvest the crops at the field. Nepal is an agricultural country having 66 percent of people directly engaged in farming. Farming is subsistent in nature and crop is mostly integrated with livestock. 

According to the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), generally to mostly cloudy in the rest of the country for a couple of days at many places of Province 1, Province 2, Bagmati Province and Gandaki Province and at a few places of Lumbini Province, Karnali Province, and Sudur Pashchim Province, chances of heavy rainfall at one or two places of Province 1, Province 2, Bagmati Province and Gandaki Province.

field_reports.description: From 04 October 2021, in three wards of Krishnagar municipality, Kapilvastu district, Lumbini Province, a diarrhoeal outbreak has occurred. As of 19 October 2021, 932 cases have been reported with symptoms of diarrhoea and vomiting. So far, 4 people, including 3 minors and a 45-year-old man have lost their lives. On 17 October 2021, four of the fecal samples have been tested positive for Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa Serotype. Cholera is endemic in the country. And, out of 15 water samples, 9 samples have tested positive for Escherichia coli.

field_reports.gov_affected_pop_centres: Nawalpur, Dhanusa, Mahottari, Chitwan, Kapilvastu, Parasi, Rautahat, Sarlahi, Synaga, Rupandehi, Dadeldhura, and Sindhuli districts
field_reports.description:
The widespread extremely heavy rainfall recorded in the last 24 hours at several places of Province 1, 2, Bagmati, Gandaki, and Lumbini of Nepal has continued to wreak havoc in more areas and inhabitants are hit by the floods. According to real-time data of the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), the water level is flowing above the danger level and there is a high flood alert in 13 rivers basin including the Bagmati river, Narayani river, Koshi river, Kamala river, and Mahakali river with high-level warning of flooding downstream to Parasi, Rautahat, Rupandehi, Kapilvastu, Chitwan, Sindhuli, Dadeldhura, Syanja and Sarlahi districts. Observing the Monsoon Monitoring and Forecast Update shared by the Government of Nepal, monsoon is not looking good for a couple of days in all the Province 1, Province 2, Bagmati Province, Gandaki Province, Karnali Province, and Sudur Pashchim Province and at one or two places of Lumbini Province of the country, with chances of continuing heavy rainfall.  
	
The floodwater in Ratu River has inundated around 900 houses in Tilgadh, Mahottari district, and around 200 households are inundated and one is missing after the flood washed away the Sunwal dam in Pasari district. Also, the flood has submerged the Nepalgunj sub-metropolitan city which has highly affected pedestrians. As the water level increased in the Doda River after the incessant rainfall more than three dozen households are inundated. Meanwhile, the flood and landslide have caused damages at different road sections, culverts, and bridges along the main highways are blocked at various locations of Lumbini Province. The destructing flood in the Danab River has swept away 14 households, around 100 households are displaced in the Rupandehi district and one person is missing. Moreover, according to different local governments, there is rising in the number of people and households affected by the calamity.

Today (1 July 2021) from the early morning sudden rise of the Kamala River to a danger level, with the potential likelihood of flooding downstream Dhanusha & Siraha is witnessed, but now the river level has receded. Also, other medium rivers like Bagmati, Marsyangdi, Budigandaki, Kaligandaki, Kankai, etc. can also rise to warn or even to danger level today. The rainfall activity is witnesses slower a bit, however, it can increase in any time soon. According to the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), heavy to moderate rain is likely to occur in the coming days in many places of the country. In addition, the DHM flood bulletin has also indicated red for almost all the terai and mid-hill districts. Based on the forecast, the alert letter has been sent to districts by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MoHA). Additionally, the Government also has the provision to send the alert SMS to the population around the river embankments in case the water level crosses the danger level. Observing the Monsoon Monitoring and Forecast Update, monsoon is not looking good for the next three days in the central and eastern part of the country, with chances of heavy rainfall activity to continue widespread across these regions. 

Due to incessant rainfall since yesterday in different parts of the country, there was a flood and landslide in some districts. Myagde Rural Municipality, Bandipur Rural Municipality, and Vyas Municipality from Tanahu district have reported two death, 3 injured affecting 95 families and 90 displaced. The displaced families are residing in public buildings and neighborhoods. Similarly, the main highway was disrupted in the Chitwan district and landslides occurred in the Gorkha districts. The IRA has been conducted in the Tanahu district and ongoing in other affected districts. Till date, a total of 1,153 families are affected, 783 families have been displaced and 576 households (fully 301 and partially 275) have been damaged across 27 districts (Sindhupalchok, Lamjung, Manang, Myagdi, Parbat, Kaski, Chitwan, Bajhang, Gorkha, Doti, Banke, Bajura, Baitadi, Dang, Humla, Panchthar, Rolpa, Jumla, Palpa, Syangja, Kalikot, Rupandehi, Kavrepalanchwok, Argakhanchi, Pyuthan, Tanahu, and Saptari).  As of 1 July 2021, 28 deaths (19 male and 9 female) have been reported, 24 are missing and 25 are injured. Due to the increased water level and current of rivers after the incessant rainfall meanwhile has caused damages at different road sections and bridges along the main highways at various locations, affecting the relief responses.

Monsoon 2021 started in the early of June for this year. With the beginning of the heavy rain since 15 June 2021 across the nation, there was a massive flood and landslides in many parts of Nepal which have caused human casualties, damage to infrastructure, crops, and livestock. In most cases, the houses were swept away and buried under the landslide debris. Till date, a total of 802 families are affected, 594 families have been displaced and 424 houses (fully 267 and partially 157) have been damaged across 20 districts (Sindhupalchok, Lamjung, Manang, Myagdi, Parbat, Kaski, Chitwan, Bajhang, Gorkha, Doti, Banke, Jumla, Palpa, Syangja, Kalikot, Rupandehi, Kavrepalanchwok, Argakhanchi, Pyuthan, and Saptari). As of 20 June 2021, 17 deaths (Male-12 and Female-5) have been reported, 22 are missing and 7 are injured. Due to the increased water level and current of rivers after the incessant rainfall meanwhile has caused damages at different road sections and bridges along the main highways at various locations, affecting the relief responses. The local governments mainly are taking the lead in responding to the incidents, with the support of communities and other humanitarian organizations. According to the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), light to moderate rain is likely to occur at many places of the country, chances of heavy rain with thunder and lightning are possible at a few places of Province 1, Province 2, and Bagmati Province and more than two places of the country. Based on the forecast, the alert letter has been sent to districts by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MoHA). Additionally, the Government also has the provision to send the alert SMS to the population around the river embankments in case the water level crosses the danger level.

NRCS district chapters immediately informed all subchapters and mobilized for further response support activities like assessment, search and rescue, and immediate relief distribution. NRCS district chapters and sub-chapters are working closely with the concerned local government, District Disaster Management Committee (DDMC), and other agencies. Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA) is completed in Sindhupalchowk, Manang, Myagdi, Kaski, Parbat, Chitwan, and Lamjung districts. 10 sub-chapters volunteers were mobilized by concerned District Chapters to support the assessment and further for relief support distribution. The first aid services are on standby position to support injured people. As of 20 June 2021, NRCS has distributed 15 sets of non-food relief items to the affected families together with 78 tarpaulins, 50 sets of utensils, 20 buckets, 30 mattresses, and 54 blankets in the Sindhupalchwok, Chitwan, and Manang district.

NRCS Emergency Operation Centre (EOC) is functional since 15 June 2021 to respond to Flood and Landslide situation. Currently, the NRCS team is also working collectively in the EOC for coordinating all relief efforts for flood and landslide responses. In addition, a number of floods and landslides that occurred since 15 June 2021 have drawn and swept away many houses in specific pocket areas of several districts and affected families are staying with their relatives, and many of them are staying in nearby schools and other temporary shelters. As result, shelter item remains one of the top-priority needs in affected areas. Likewise, displaced families have lost their water points and sanitation facilities which may aggravate the additional risk of health as well as COVID-19 and water-borne diseases. Health, clean drinking water, sanitation facilities, livelihood promotion, protection along with health and hygiene promotion support is needed in the flood and landslide affected areas. NRCS headquarters is keeping additional National Disaster Response Team (NDRT) members on standby for deployment as needed. IFRC Nepal country office, in close coordination with the NRCS, in-country Movement partners is monitoring the situation regularly. A joint team comprising staff from NRCS and IFRC is working together to develop a Pro-forma emergency plan of action (EPOA) and budget in case there is a need to request DREF funding to assist more affected people. Danish Red Cross team is closely working together with the NRCS team to collect IRA reports, consolidate reports and prepare daily situation reports and IFRC is supporting NRCS to update the GO platform among Movement Partners. Currently, NRCS received USD 50,000 (fifty thousand) from American Red Cross Quick Action Fund (QAF) to respond to floods and landslides in Sindhupalchowk, Lamjung, and Manang districts.

The continuous rainfall from 15 June has caused heavy flooding and landslide in various parts of the country. The most affected district includes Sindhupalchok, Lamjung, Manang, and Myagdi. The districts have witness devastating floods and landslides with hundreds being displaced and loss of properties worth millions of rupees. So far, 8 people have confirmed missing in Sindhupalchok district (seven) and one in Dailakh district. In addition, the Department of Hydrology has predicted that the rainfall will be intense for two more days mostly in the western part of the country. As well as the department has predicted that there will be more than average rainfall in this monsoon. 

In response to the rainfall, NRCS has distributed 50 tarpaulins, 50 sets of utensils, and 50 blankets in the Manang district. An Initial Rapid Assessment (IRA) has been conducted in Manang, Myagdi, and Lamjung districts. NRCS is regularly coordinating with local stakeholders and participating in meetings called by DDMC in affected districts. IFRC is providing technical support to NRCS in finalizing the Performa EPoA and update in the GO platform among others.

Nepal has been experiencing persistent torrential rains since mid-June 2022, causing widespread flash flooding and landslides in several regions of the country. Recently, following heavy rainfall on the October-first week of 2022, three provinces, namely Lumbini, Karnali, and Sudhurpaschim reported incidents of flooding and landslides. The initial assessments by Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS) through its provincial and district chapters in affected provinces for these recent floods and landslides indicate that 375 houses have been reported fully damaged, with further 3,227 houses partially destroyed. In addition, around 15,555 families are affected including 13,101 families temporarily displaced. Nepal Government authorities have reported 19 people have died, 10 injured, and over 9 missing, while further search and rescue are underway. The scale of this disaster calls for an immediate major relief response from the government and other in-country agencies. Likewise, as the harvesting season is near, hundreds of acres of farming fields have reportedly been damaged and destroyed. The detailed assessment with coordinated efforts by NRCS including relief agencies to ascertain the extent of the damage is underway. The department of hydrology and meteorology has issued warnings for heavy rain in several provinces including the rising of water levels in major rivers. Also, predicting still possible rain in some areas.

results.name: Nepal - Monsoon Floods and Landslides
results.summary:
The monsoon rains that began in the last week of June have triggered flooding and landslides in many parts of the
country, affecting around 10,000 families in 56 out of the country’s 77 districts in various ways. Since the monsoon
season began, NRCS has responded at the local level with technical and financial support from the IFRC and in-country
Partners. The monsoon season typically starts in July and lasts until mid-September, resulting in floods and landslides
across many districts of the country due to heavy rainfall. Each year, floods and landslides affect an average of 10,000
families, leaving many people homeless who face various challenges in coping with the situation and meeting immediate
humanitarian needs on their own (Source: Nepal Disaster Report 2019).
On 26 August, rainfall intensified for at least four consecutive days, with many rivers crossing warning levels, causing
widespread inundation in many parts of the southern plains and reported incidents of landslides in the hilly region. As a
result of this incessant rainfall, 11 districts (Myagdi, Rupandehi, Dang, Darchula, Sindhuli, Nawalparasi East,
Nawalparasi West, Kanchanpur, Kailali, Udayapur and Mahottari) and 4,899 families were affected, including 2,129 who
were temporarily displaced. In addition, government authorities have reported seven deaths and one missing person in
recent days (as of 31 August 2021), while further assessment processes are underway.
